moves.1. e4: This game features a positional Sveshnikov opening, resulting in a very interesting endgame. Let's start!
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: The Svesh is one of the most thouroghly analyzed openings in the world, so this is well-known and standard.
moves.13... f4: This move is critisized by maybe the greatest Svesh expert, GM Rogozenko. He says that black should not close the position in the centre, since white can now break with g3 at a convenient time.
moves.14. c4 b4 15. Nc2 Rb8 16. g3: the g3-break. A plan might be Kh1, Rg1 and gf4.
moves.16... b3 17. axb3 Rxb3 18. Ra3: I most admit that Rxa6 probably was better. With this move I tried a "no counterplay-strategy". Black's only active piece is exchanged.
moves.18... Rxa3 19. bxa3: Opening the b-file for the rook.
moves.19... h6 20. Rb1 fxg3 21. hxg3 O-O 22. N: I was very happy with this position: I have to do something dramatic to manage to lose, and playing for a win is fully possible. We are playing for two results, as the Russian chesschool would say.
moves.26... Re8 27. Be4 Ra8 28. a4 a5 29. Kg2: Okey, so I didn't manage to do anything with the rook, maybe I can try the queen and bishop endgame?
I thought this was good, but afterwards I admit that playing with the queens on would've given more winning chances.
moves.38... Qxc6 39. dxc6 d5: !! Maybe not a difficult move for such a strong player as vortx, but for more casual players, this is worth noting: Black's terribly weak bishop must be activated, even at the cost of a pawn. This move saves the draw.
moves.42. Kf3 Bc5 43. Ke4: Okey, so now I got a bit optimistic. Trying to win a drawn position might be very risky.
moves.47. Bd5 e3 48. Bf3 h5 49. Kg5 h4 50. Kg4: The game will finish in a draw: 50...e2 51.Bxe2 Kxc6 52.f6 Kd7  and the king rushes to block the pawn with a easy draw. In the game I thought black would win the a4-pawn, so maybe I should've played on. As a good rule: Always play to checkmate or only kings left!
